sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying ring
message_1: A circular loop of wire with a radius of 0.1 meters carries a current of 2 amperes. What is the magnitude and direction of the magnetic field at a distance of 0.05 meters from the center of the loop if the current flows clockwise?
message_2:
To find the magnetic field at a point on the axis of the circular loop, we can use the formula:

B = (μ₀ * I * R²) / (2 * (R² + x²)^(3/2))

where B is the magnetic field, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A), I is the current, R is the radius of the loop, and x is the distance from the center of the loop.

Given values:
I = 2 A
R = 0.1 m
x = 0.05 m

Plugging in the values:

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 2 A * (0.1 m)²) / (2 * ((0.1 m)² + (0.05 m)²)^(3/2))

B = (8π × 10^(-7) Tm * 0.01 m²) / (2 * (0.01 m² + 0.0025 m²)^(3/2))

B = (8π × 10^(-7) Tm * 0.01 m²) / (2 * (0.0125 m²)^(3/2))

B ≈ 1.34 × 10^(-5) T

The direction of the magnetic field can be determined using the right-hand rule. Since the current flows clockwise, if you curl the fingers of your right hand in the direction of the current, your thumb will point in the direction of the magnetic field. In this case, the magnetic field direction will be into the plane (or downward) at the point 0.05 meters from the center of the loop.

So, the magnitude of the magnetic field is approximately 1.34 × 10^(-5) T, and the direction is into the plane (or downward).
